intro: Lepidium anglicum, commonly known as peppergrass, is a flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is a low-growing annual or biennial herb that typically reaches heights of 10–30 centimeters. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes, and its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and often covered in fine hairs. It is native to Europe and parts of Asia but has been introduced to other regions, including North America. Peppergrass is often found in disturbed soils, such as roadsides and fields, and is known for its peppery scent when crushed.
